title: Navalny calls for release of political prisoners at Moscow rally
text:
More than 20,000 people rallied in Moscow on Sunday (September 29) to demand the release of protesters that have been jailed

in what Kremlin opponents say is a campaign to stifle dissent.

Russian opposition leader and Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny joined Sunday's protest- hopeful that more prisoners will be released.

(SOUNDBITE) (Russian) OPPOSITION LEADER AND KREMLIN CRITIC ALEXEI NAVALNY, SAYING (TALKING ABOUT THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE ATTENDING RALLY):

"This is a big evolution of our society. Unfortunately, there have been political prisoners in Russia since at least 2003. But now we see that it has really become a mass people's movement, and I am sure that more people will be released because of this rally. But in any case this will be a long and complicated process, and we are just at the beginning of it."

The detained protesters were arrested during demonstrations that have been ongoing since July against the exclusion of many opposition candidates from a Moscow election.

Authorities say they were breaking the law and that the protests had to be dispersed as they had not been authorized and were therefore illegal.

Sunday's rally was authorised by the city's mayor's office, meaning mass detentions are less likely to occur.
